climbs.name: British/American Route ['Scott Route']
climbs.fa: Paul 'Tut' Braithwaite, Dennis Hennek, Paul Nunn, Doug Scott; 1972

content.description:
Starts towards the lefthand side of the East Face's lower apron, aiming for an obvious crack system in the narrow headwall far above. The crux is the penultimate headwall pitch, a lieback/offwidth/squeeze. Originally done in 40 pitches or thereabouts, using 150ft/45m ropes; modern ascents seem to get it down to about 25. A line of bolts may still be present on the otherwise quite bold crux pitch; these unwelcome and unnecessary additions appeared a couple of decades or so after the first ascent and clearly detract from the challenge and commitment of the route.

Trad gear. Reportedly some belay/rappel anchors in place. Retro-bolts possibly still present on crux pitch.

climbs.name: Polar Thievery
climbs.fa: Grant Statham, Mark Klassen, Tom Fayle, May 1998

content.description:
A great way to summit Asgard without a committing route and much better rock than the Swiss route. 
From the base ~200m of 4th and 5th class slabs will get you to the bowl, then 70m of 5th will get you to a ledge at the base of the head wall , where the climbing begins. 
Great climbing down low brings you to the crux off-width chimney at 5.11a , youll have to squirm your way up and out to a final alcove with some steeper exit moves or slither through the cold and wet tunnel to the summit. 

Climbers right of the notch, but not quite on the northern skyline. 
double rack to 3", one 4' and 5"; double 60m ropes

The North Tower of Asgard host amazing rock quality and long sustained  & athletic lines.  
 Most parties will opt for the mega classic 23-pitch Scott Route, but options for new ascents and other quality lines are bountiful.
